segments.text: This is an interview with retired Army Major Edward John Carter by John Martin on November 27, 1988, in San Antonio, Texas, concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about the war, I am going to donate this tape to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
Yes, it is.
OK.
Can you please state your place and date of birth?
I was born in Spokane, Washington on 26 June 1946.
OK. What is the extent of your education before the war, and what is it now?
Before I entered the service, I had completed two years of college.
Since my participation in the Vietnam War,
I have graduated from college and am now in pursuit of a master's degree in business administration.
How and why did you join the Army?
I joined the Army in February of 1967, primarily to beat the draft because I wanted to fly helicopters.
I enlisted for the Warrant Officer Flight Program.
Okay.
Can you give a brief sketch of your military career?
I completed basic training, Army flight training, and attack helicopter training.
Went to Vietnam for one year.
Upon completion of my tour in Vietnam, I served as an attack helicopter instructor pilot and was commissioned in armor.
Served several ground command assignments and staff assignments, aviation staff and operational assignments.
and ended up my career in installation level staff and finally flag headquarters staff assignments.
What type of training did you receive before your tour in Vietnam?
Well, I received a standard basic training, eight-week basic combat training at Fort Pope, Louisiana, followed by my Army flight training at Fort Walters.
Texas, Fort Rucker, Alabama, then my attack helicopter training in Savannah, Georgia prior to going to Vietnam.
When was your tour in Vietnam?
This is June 1968, June 1969.
Okay, and what unit were you with?
I was assigned to Air Cavalry Troop, 11th Armored Cavalry Regiment, located in the III Corps area of Vietnam, more precisely, Ben Hoa area.
Do you believe the training you received prepare you for Vietnam?
Well, from an operational standpoint and learning the tactics of helicopter employment and attack helicopter employment, I think I was very well prepared.
I was certainly very confident in my ability to operate a helicopter.
When I first got over there, I wasn't real confident in my ability to conform to tactics or just what it would be like to be shot at.
I think I was well prepared.
I guess about as well as anybody.
Was there anything that you weren't prepared for
Well, I can't think of anything.
Maybe then, other than what would you do if you were shot down and captured, that was kind of a lax.
We had probably a week of escape and evasion, which consisted mostly of an overnight exercise where you had to keep from getting caught.
But the pressure wasn't really
like it would be if you were really trying to get away from being captured.
I don't know, I guess I always wondered how would I react or what would I do if I had been shot down and captured.
What was your biggest fear in Vietnam?
Well, being an attack helicopter pilot, probably my biggest fear was killing some of our own people with my bullets.
several times that things would be happening.
They'd be calling for the bullets 25 to 50 meters from their position.
And with the inherent inaccuracy of the rockets, it really scared you to shoot that close to the friendlies.
That was probably my biggest fear.
The next biggest fear was incoming at night.
into our compound.
I was trying to sleep.
You know, fear of the unknown.
Nothing you can control that tends to make you somewhat fearful.
When you were flying, was there ever the fear of being shot down or shot at?
Oh, sure.
You're always afraid that something's going to happen to you,
I guess as you spend more time over there, you tend to lose that fear.
You start concentrating on your task at hand more than being shot at until you get close to going home.
It was really funny.
The closer guys used to get to going home, the higher they'd start flying at 100 feet from Mama.
100 feet for baby, 100 feet for whoever you could think of.
It would kind of run in, I guess, in a cycle.
When you first got there, you were very cautious.
As you got through the first third, midway to two-thirds and three-quarters of your tour, that caution kind of started to go away.
And then as you got closer to going home, you'd start to get more cautious again.
What were your living conditions like?
I had it real good.
We lived at our Black Horse Base Camp was the regimental area.
It was well established.
It had been established a couple of years prior to my arrival with the unit.
The area in Benoit that we used, all of them, we all lived in wooden hoochies with metal roofs, plenty of sandbags.
We slept on cots with air mattresses and mosquito nets.
We had clean clothes and three hot meals if you weren't flying through the meal.
So we had it real good compared to the guys in the bush.
What was a typical day in Vietnam, or was there some kind of routine that you had?
Well, not really.
a set routine.
The function of my unit was reconnaissance.

The 11th Armored Cab Regiment had three ground squadrons, which were comprised of tanks and APCs and what have you, and one air cab troop, which was us, and our mission was to go out and scout around and try and find signs of the enemy, and at that point allow the
direct the ground troops into searching or what have you, that area.
There was generally two statuses that you could be on.
You would either fly a mission with your OH-6 and what we called a pink team, just the two of you out in your little area trying to find trouble or signs of bad guys.
Then the other status would be as a fire team, two Cobras.
on standby, ready to go any time.
You just kind of alternate between those statuses.
Briefings were usually held at 630 in the morning.
And you just took what the day gave you from that point on.
When you were on call as a fire team, you usually sat for a 24-hour period.
You couldn't go anywhere.
You had to stay close to the aircraft.
And that's probably where I put in some of my longest days, was getting scrambled at 4 o'clock in the morning and flying pretty much throughout the whole day.
I had a couple 14- and 16-hour days of actual flight time in that status.
The hunter-killer or pink team concept was very boring for me.
The scout was down snooping around the area and
In the Cobra, you were up above them just flying in circles.
Circles for eight hours a day was not a lot of fun.
How was your unit employed to fight the war?
Primarily in reconnaissance.
Our regimental commander was George S. Patton III.
And when he assumed command of the regiment, he had
paper mimeographed with the following order placed above the doorway of every doorway in the regimental area.
It simply stated, standing order for troopers of the 11th US cavalry.
Find the bastards and pile on.
And that's the way we lived.
Do you believe your operations were successful in fighting the Viet Cong and the North Vietnamese army?
Well, I think we were very successful in finding the bastards and piling on.
But as far as do I think we were winning or were we losing, I don't think I'll ever really know because it seemed like you never made any headway.
You were busy in one area.
You'd fight them for a while,
You'd go somewhere else, and then you'd end up back in the same area again six weeks later.
And I just don't really know that we did any good.
We did good, but we killed a lot of them.
But it seemed like there were always some there to replace them.
And I think if the war would have had a more defined front, you could see moving backwards or forwards.
so you could determine whether or not you're losing or winning the war.

Probably would have been a little easier for everybody to understand it, but when the front was outside the wire, like you say sometimes, inside the wire doing TAD, you really don't get a good feeling.
You don't get any feedback as to your success or failure.
All you know is you're out there every day.
Was it frustrating?
Very frustrating.
Very frustrating.
I think most people like to have that feedback.
Are you doing well or are you not doing well?
You just really didn't get that feedback.
What type of problems were you in?
Were there any drug problems or problems with careers?
People want to boast their careers or fragging?
There really wasn't any drug problems at the beginning of my year in Vietnam.
Maybe a crew chief now or then would get caught with some marijuana.
It started to get a little worse amongst the blue platoon, the air rifle platoon, which was the infantry platoon we had as part of the unit.
Near the end of my tour,
probably the last three or four months before I came home.
And I think at that point in time, things had started to slow down a little bit, and they had more time on their hands.
They weren't out actively engaged with the bad guys every day, so there was a little more tendency, I think, to,
to go for drugs for something to do.
But early in my tour, the blue platoon was very, very active.
They were constantly out in the field.
So I think they were probably tended not to use them.
As far as the pilots using drugs, I only know of one that ever did.
He was in the lift platoon, and he was kind of
kind of a weirdo anyway, but he got caught and court-martialed.
As far as careerism, yes.
My commanding officer, West Point graduate.
In fact, Patton was his TAC officer at West Point when he was a student.
seized this opportunity to move his career up the ladder.
He eventually retired as a general officer.
And his mannerisms were quite the same as Patton.
If you ever watched the movie Patton, the son was pretty much the same.
Wore the pearl handle, excuse me, ivory handle, 45.
Curls for pimps.
And Bonson was pretty much in the same mold, that type of person, personality.
Never was any fraggings while I was there, I think.
Fraggings didn't become the end thing until after I left, as far as Vietnam goes.
Were there any other problems that you can think of
No, as far as just the day-to-day things.
Was there any racism?
No, funny, there wasn't.
We had black pilots and white pilots.
In the air rifle platoons, there was blacks, whites, Hispanics.
In fact, my best friend in Vietnam was black.
We got along very well.
I think when you get a job to do,
and there's a tough task, the color barriers or racial barriers start to go away because everybody's pulling together, aimed at the accomplishment of that one task.
From that standpoint, I don't think they're learning.
What did you think of the Vietnamese people and their culture?
Well, I thought they were certainly
backward compared to the way I grew up.
I grew up in primarily an agricultural part of the United States.
And I knew how we farmed.
And to watch the way they farmed using antiquated methods, oxen and water buffalo and what have you, it just seemed like they weren't smart enough to keep up with the times.
Or maybe they just couldn't afford it.
I don't know.
Their farms were so poor.
The country itself was an absolutely beautiful country.
It was too bad it had to be scarred by war.
I never really got to know the people.
Some of the units over there were allowed to have hooch maids, and people would come and wash their clothes and clean their hooch.
We weren't allowed to have them.
So we had basically no contact with the Vietnamese people at all, or I didn't.
So I really can't comment.
Did the Army ever give you any type of training on Vietnam or the culture?
The people's culture?
No.
If they did, it didn't impress me or I slept through it.
I must have slept through it because it sure didn't.
I still don't remember ever having any training to that type.
Did you have any contact with ARVN?
We did some, had some operations with the Arvin troops.
Of course, we didn't talk to the, I didn't talk to the Arvin troops.
I talked to the advisor.
The American advisor was who I'd talk to on the radio.
I can remember one bad experience with them that I thought they were a bunch of chickens.
In fact, they were

their helicopters came in the area and there was some some ground fire going on they just turned around and left they were supposed to resupply their own soldiers and they just fled the area they didn't even make their drop and i remember having to chase them in my aircraft and actually shoot a burst of minigun across their nose to make them turn around and go back and land and drop their bullets and resupply but that was that was a bad experience the
The other few times that I did work with the Arvin soldiers, they seemed to do pretty well.
They were fighting well, fighting hard.
Just that one incident where they appeared to be running rather than fighting.
What did you think of your enemy?
When you were there, it was pretty much an MPA at the time, more than BC, or was it?
Both.
And very resourceful.
I've got to admire their resourcefulness.
They could take pieces of nothing and make weapons out of them.
Some of the devices that they used to set off rockets, a GI wristwatch and a battery, put their rockets on cross dates.
They'd use a homemade gunner's quadrant to set the launch angle.
They'd hook both wires to the battery, one to the case on the watch, and the other, they'd drill a small hole through the crystal at 12 o'clock.
They'd set the watch with the long hand at 5 past the hour.
And 55 minutes later, when the long hand contacted the wire,
that was stuck through the crystal, the rockets would launch.
That gave them almost an hour to get away.
Very ingenious.
Very sneaky.
I guess where you couldn't tell the bad guys from the good guys, it helped them.
Guerrilla warfare is very effective in that way.
I guess that was a source of frustration.
Couldn't really tell them who the bad guys were.
While you were in Vietnam, did you get a lot of notice about the demonstrations against the war back home?
Did y'all hear about it while you were in Vietnam?
I get some of it now and then.
I guess the flower children were, everybody knew about the flower children and flower power and all of that.
Personally, I didn't pay much attention to it.
more important things to worry about, namely my butt.
If you've seen the movie Good Morning Vietnam, the new censorship, I think, portrayed in the movie was probably a little overboard of what it really was.
But it wasn't censored that bad.
I don't think it did.
Of course, I've got no way of knowing.
I was there and not here.
What did you think about the protesters when you finished your tour and you were back home?
They were kind of angry.
I don't think they really knew.
A lot of them knew what they were protesting about.
I think they were just...
like cattle following the leader.
Some of them knew what they were protesting about, but an awful lot of them didn't.
I guess I kind of blamed the press, the media, for a lot.
I don't know.
After I got back from Vietnam and had been there, you see some of the newscasts.
Now, I know it really didn't happen the way they're portraying it.
I think sometimes they were very negative against our being there.
They would take the opportunity to distort a story a little bit to maybe keep the American people upset about it, I guess.
So do you believe the press should have been held back from, or should have been somewhat censored by the Army
No, I don't think you can do that and have freedom of the press.
I think the press and the media need to be there, but they need to, I don't know if you can do that or not, if there is such a thing as having a neutral view rather than a hawkish or dovish.
If they just wouldn't put their own opinions into it all the time, I think, if the correspondent wouldn't
strictly write his stories from his viewpoint.
What was your opinion on the draft?
Well, I enlisted to beat the draft.
I think that the value of the draft became more evident later on in my honorary career when I commanded a basic training company, right at the change from a draft to an all-volunteer.
I saw just one example.
I saw the average education level of a class of trainees, a company of trainees, 225 trainees.
The average education level go from 14 years to nine years within just a couple cycles.
So I think as a draft, with the draft, you get a better cross-section of the people in the United States than you do with an all-volunteer.
Do you have an opinion about
those men that decided to join the National Guard or to go to Canada?
Well, I think that's two separate issues.
As far as joining the National Guard or Reserves, I had the same opportunity.
I could have.
In fact, the day that I heard about the Warrant Officer Flight Program on the radio, I had just come from an interview with the Reserves, the Army Reserves.
A friend of mine and I had gone for an interview, and I heard about the Warrant Officer Flight Program.
He went on and joined the Reserves, and I came on active duty.
He's still in the Reserves, and I'm retired.
There were Reserves who served in Vietnam and National Guard.
So, yeah, they, you know,
Some people perceived it as an out, something to do to escape having to go to Vietnam.
I had the same opportunity and didn't take it.
But do you have an opinion about those who went to Canada?
Yeah, I have a definite opinion about those cowardly SOBs.
Okay.
They shouldn't let them back in the country.
Do you believe the U.S. could have won the war?
Yes.
Yes.
And why?
Well, first off, I think the commanders over there were too hamstrung by the politicians.
I think if...
Goals could have been established, definite goals that were supportable by the United States government.
And if they had just turned the leadership loose over there to conduct the war the way they knew how, perhaps we'd have made a little better showing over there.
I think Congress being what they are, I think
They hamstrung us too much, and I think there were a lot of lives lost needlessly.
It would not have been lost if we had given it more commitment as a nation.
Do you think that if the U.S. would have declared war, the nation would have been able to get behind it more, or do you think it probably wouldn't have done anything?
I guess I might be contradicting myself.
I don't think the American people wanted to support a war.
At that point in time, it probably would have taken something as drastic as the bombing of Pearl Harbor only here in the United States to shake the people loose into reality.
It's hard to say what it would have taken to get the U.S. people behind it, totally committed like they were in World War II.
If you had to do all over again, would you go back to Vietnam, go back to that time, would you?
Yes.
Like I said, 21 years in the Army.
That's really the only, that one year I was doing what I was trained to do, and that's fight.
The rest of the 21 years, I was either training people to be prepared or trying to be prepared myself.
It's easier to fight the peacetime moment.
